case_vignette: A 72-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for forgetfulness, confusion, and mood changes for the past 4 months. His symptoms started with misplacing items such as his wallet and keys around the house. Two months ago, he became unable to manage their finances as it became too difficult for him. Last week, he became lost while returning home from the grocery store. His wife reports that he shows “no emotion” and that he is seemingly not concerned by his recent symptoms. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, metformin, and rosuvastatin. His pulse is 56/min and blood pressure is 158/76 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows loss of sensation on his right leg and an unsteady gait. When asked to stand with his eyes closed and palms facing upward, his right arm rotates inward. An MRI of the brain shows multiple deep white matter lesions.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been forgetful, confused, and my mood has been changing for about 4 months.
How old are you?
I am 72 years old.
Do you have any medical history or take any medications?
Yes, I have high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease, and I take aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, metformin, and rosuvastatin.
Any family history of neurological conditions like Alzheimer's disease or dementia?
I don't know, you didn't tell me.
I apologize for the confusion. Does anyone in your family have a history of Alzheimer's disease or dementia?
I don't know, you didn't tell me.

I understand, thank you. Based on your symptoms, medical history, and age, I suspect you may be experiencing symptoms of Alzheimer's disease or another form of dementia. I would recommend further evaluation by a neurologist for a definitive diagnosis.
